title: Jacobson on womens clubs in Oklahoma - purpose

content.description:
“The [objective of the] Oklahoma State Federation of Negro Women's Clubs...[is to] raise to the highest plane the home, the moral, intellectual, and civil life of the race and to cultivate that spirit of general helpfulness, as expressed in its motto, ‘Lifting as We Climb.’...
This organization is promoting work along all lines of educational and civic improvement in many of the cities and towns of the state.... One club has a day nursery and lunch room for school children.... Another club furnished properly chaperoned weekly entertainments for the young people.
[The] Muskogee and El Reno clubs are promoting public libraries and hospitals. Many clubs all over the state are furnishing playgrounds for the children.”
Library of Congress
Source: Mrs. H. P. Jacobson, “Negro Women’s Club Work in Oklahoma,” The Tulsa Star, August 15, 1914
content.question: Which of the following best describes the author’s primary purpose in the source?

choices.label: To highlight the achievements of individual club members
To showcase the achievements of African American women in community development
To criticize the lack of government support for community initiatives
To advocate for increased funding for public libraries and hospitals

content.answer: To showcase the achievements of African American women in community development

topic.text: 3.8: Lifting as We Climb: Uplift Ideologies and Black Women's Rights and Leadership

skill.text: 2.B: Describe a source's perspective, purpose, context, and audience.
